items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake levels are high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Lake levels remain high but are beginning to fall, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow evening. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

As a result of high spring tides, flooding is possible along the Coast at North Morecambe Bay. This evening’s tide on 25/11/2022 does not quite meet Flood Alert but as tides remain high and will reach Flood Alert levels on 26/11/2022, the Flood Alert will remain in force. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. Tides are expected to remain at Flood Alert levels into the weekend. We are not expecting to issue any Flood Warnings at this time. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in the area. This message will be updated on 26/11/2022, 9:00AM or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force due to high tides that may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Friday 25/11/2022, between 6:00pm and 8:15pm. The particular area at risk is around Kilnsea village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 10pm on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to high tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Friday 25/11/2022, between 6:15 PM and 7:45 PM. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10pm on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.86mAOD at 15:30 on 25/11/22 and 4.83mAOD at 03:30 on 26/11/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 114 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high on the River Foulness at Welham Bridge due to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Foulness. River levels elsewhere in this catchment are not currently of concern. Scattered showers are expected today, Friday 25/11/2022, with further rainfall forecast tomorrow, Saturday 26/11/2022 and we expect levels to remain high. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10pm on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill areas. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. The weather forecast is dry today with showers tomorrow. Levels have stabilised on the Wey but will remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of Heavy rain.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is to continue between 12:00 today 25/11/22 and over the weekend.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 27/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning Saturday 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Further rainfall is forecast overnight Saturday 26/11/22. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    No further rainfall is forecast today.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels are falling at the Tamworth River gauge. Further showers are forecast over the next 12 hours.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today (25/11/2022). Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads between Water Orton and Tamworth including the Bourne Brook at Fazeley.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby road, the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook

items.message: River levels have risen at the Hints river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday 24/11/22. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 25/11/22. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook. Further showers is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into this evening 25/11/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. The levels are predicted to rise again as a result of the forecast rain overnight on Sunday 27/11/22 and into Monday 28/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Saturday, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Levels are currently falling on the Chertsey Bourne but may rise and come out of banks again due to additional rainfall. The forecast is dry today with showers tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but generally steady at the Willington and Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12. We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
Tides are now receding and as a result there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.  Strong winds are possible over the weekend. This brings a risk of some large waves at times. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to remain careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and wind and wave conditions have calmed.

As a result of high spring tides, flooding is possible along the coast from Gretna to Silloth. The tides are high but not expected to reach Flood Alert on 25/11/2022 or 26/11/2022.  This Flood Alert remains in place for the high tide 27/11/2022 between 01:15 AM and 01:45 AM. Flooding is possible one hour either side of this time. We are not expecting to issue any Flood Warnings at this time. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in the area. This message will be updated on 26/11/2022, 9:00AM or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 27/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 21:00, 25/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now passed. Last night’s tide at Portsmouth (23:32 on Thursday 24/11/2022) was recorded at 5.13m Chart Datum (2.40 mAOD). This was not as high as we expected. Over the next week, tide levels are significantly lower than last night (24/11/2022). We are not expecting further impacts as a result.

River levels have risen at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 26/11/22 or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.

We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high at the Eathorpe river gauge consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today (25/11/2022). Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.  
Scattered blustery showers is forecast in the next 12 hours. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have cleared weed screens ahead of this forecasted rain.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks Llanymynech peaked at 3.58m this morning 25/11/22.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is higher than normal, but is currently slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and possibly the gardens of properties near Mock Bridge on Friday. Friday should stay mostly dry. River levels will continue to fall through Friday and Saturday. However, a lot of rain (50mm) is forecast from 20:00 Saturday evening 26/11/2022. The River Adur will rise and could cause property flooding at Mock Bridge. River levels could rise to a similar height of the peak Thursday 17 November 2022. River levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until the middle of next week. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 26/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains higher than normal. Yesterday, 8mm of rain was recorded at Wroxhall in 2 hours. This caused the river to slightly rise at Alverstone, but currently, it is falling by approximately 2cm per hour. At Sandown, the level is stable and is expected to begin falling again today. Residual flood impacts affecting roads, cycle tracks and footpaths throughout the Yar Valley will continue throughout today (25/11/22). At Sandown, the ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Further rainfall (up to 40mm) is forecast on Saturday evening and into Sunday (27/11/2022). So, while levels will fall today, the river will rise in response to this forecast rain. Property flooding may occur. We are operating Bembridge sluice to manage water levels in Brading marshes. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Saturday 26/11/2022.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday, Thursday 24 November. The river levels will remain high for the next 12 hours. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible around Kinnersley Manor. Property flooding is not currently expected.   
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 8pm Friday 25 November 2022.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message: River levels are falling, however further rainfall is forecast for Saturday 26th November. We expect rivers to respond later on Saturday. We anticipate issuing a flood alert for this incoming rain.

The Western Rother is higher than normal between Midhurst and FIttleworth but is now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens near Fittleworth. Friday should stay mostly dry. River levels will continue to fall through Friday and Saturday. However, a lot of rain (50mm) is forecast from 20:00 Saturday evening 26/11/2022. River levels will rise in all communities and could cause property flooding along the length of the Western Rother. River levels could possibly rise higher than the peaks of last week. River levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until next week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 26/11/2022.

Saturday's early morning tide at 00:15 on 26/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by high energy waves. Winds are light Westerly Force 3. The weather increases tide table values by 0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 6.01 metres Chart Datum (2.96 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Saturday's midday tide will be very similar and minor impacts should be expected again. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 26/11/2022.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, following twice the monthly average rainfall in November, but is now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. In Barnham, only minimal impacts are currently expected, with river levels comparatively lower. Friday should stay mostly dry. River levels will continue to fall through Saturday. However a lot of rain (50mm) is forecast from 20:00 Saturday evening 26/11/2022. River levels will rise on both the Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes. Possibly even higher than the peak of last week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 20:00 26/11/2022.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now passed. Last night’s tide at Portsmouth (23:32 on Thursday 24/11/2022) was recorded at 5.13m Chart Datum (2.40 mAOD). This was not as high as we expected. Over the next week, tide levels are significantly lower than last night (24/11/2022). We are not expecting further impacts as a result.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now passed. Last night’s tide at Portsmouth (23:32 on Thursday 24/11/2022) was recorded at 5.13m Chart Datum (2.40 mAOD). This was not as high as we expected. Over the next week, tide levels are significantly lower than last night (24/11/2022). We are not expecting further impacts as a result.

items.message:
The river level on the Washford River at Beggearn Huish remains high and above the flood alert level but is currently stable. All other rivers are currently below levels of concern. A mostly dry day is forecast for today, Friday 25/11/22, but further wet weather is forecast to return during Saturday afternoon and into Sunday with the possibility of flooding of low-lying land and roads. The flooding of properties is not forecast at this time. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 25/11/22.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.
We expect river levels to begin falling throughout Friday 25/11/22 but are predicted to rise due to the forecast rainfall on Sunday night 27/11/22 and into Monday 28/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.
This message will be updated Saturday, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.54 m and is currently falling by 5 mm per hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.28 m and is currently stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load above 7.86 m and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m. Property flooding is not expected at this time. Pumping will take place at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station when river levels allow.
A mostly dry day is forecast for today, Friday 25/11/22, but further wet weather is forecast to return during Saturday afternoon and into Sunday with the possibility of flooding of low-lying land and roads.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
River levels are continuing to fall at the Covington Brook river gauge this afternoon but remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 25/11/22. Flooding is affecting the River Kym and River Til from Yelden and Upper Dean to Hail Weston. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Riseley river gauge this afternoon but remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 25/11/22. Flooding is affecting Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.54m and is currently falling by 15mm per hour. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.99m and is rising by 10mm per hour. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30m. Flooding of properties is not forecast and pumping will take place at Currymoor as soon as river levels allow. 
A mostly dry day is forecast for today, Friday 25/11/22, but further wet weather is forecast to return during Saturday afternoon and into Sunday with the possibility of flooding of low-lying land and roads.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 26/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded.

Continued bands of heavy rain have fallen onto saturated ground in the Upper River Witham catchment.  River levels remain high. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout Friday 25th November and into the weekend with further rain forecast overnight Saturday. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday 26th November or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam and Frisby river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding of farm land and low lying roads in the Melton and Asfordby areas, including Station Lane Ashfordly including low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent heavy rainfall. Levels in York will remain high today, Friday, 25/11/2022. Flooding of low-lying land is expected. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Scattered showers are expected today, Friday 25/11/2022, with further rainfall forecast tomorrow, Saturday 26/11/2022 and we expect levels to remain high. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts. This message will be updated by 10pm on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: The risk of flooding from the East and West Glens has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Alconbury Brook river gauge this afternoon but remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 25/11/22. Flooding is affecting Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconbury’s, Little Stukley and Brampton. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected in locations near the River Derwent, particularly low lying land upstream of Malton, on Friday, 25/11/2022. Scattered showers are expected today, Friday 25/11/2022, with further rainfall forecast tomorrow, Saturday 26/11/2022, and river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10pm on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Scattered showers are expected today, Friday 25/11/2022, with further rainfall forecast tomorrow, Saturday 26/11/2022 and river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially in the areas around Thrupp. We are not expecting rainfall over night tonight, but some showers will cross the area Saturday evening. We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Saturday, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated  by 10am on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Croxall river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue between 12:00 today 25/11/22 and over the weekend.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent.    
No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 27/11/22 .
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning Saturday 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend and river levels may rise again in response to this. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This Flood Alert has been removed.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels remain high at the Besford Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford. Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore. Local fords may also be flooded. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 26/11/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Recent heavy bands of rain have caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

River levels have risen at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and low lying land at Quedgeley / Stonebench. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.5m and 3.8m Monday evening, 28/11/22, Upper Pound 3.5m and 3.8m Monday evening, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 26/11/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides are due this evening 25/11/22, and tomorrow morning 26/11/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.7m to 4m at 22:45 this evening 25/11/22, 3.7m to 4m at 11:00 tomorrow morning 26/11/22. Gloucester 3.4m to 3.7m at 22:15 this evening 25/11/2022, 3.4m to 3.7m at 10:30 tomorrow morning 26/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting the racecourse and the Worcester County cricket ground. Predicted peaks:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.2m to 5.6m Monday morning, 28/11/22. Diglis 3.1m to 3.4m Monday morning, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 26/11/22 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Evesham and Bredon river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 26/11/22 or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is now operational. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.2m to 5.6m Monday morning, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 26/11/22 or as the situation changes.

Saturday's early morning tide at 00:18 on 26/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by high energy waves. Winds are light South Westerly Force 2. The weather increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 5.00 metres Chart Datum (2.27 mAOD) at Portsmouth. This may cause overtopping into beach front gardens at Southwood Road, Bembridge Drive, Meath Close and The Strand. Property flooding is not expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with the local authority and their response teams over the condition of the beach at South Hayling. Successive tides have removed some of the shingle which helps to protect South Hayling and South Eastoke. The excavator has been on site re-forming the beach crest. At high tide, waves and water may be higher up the beach than normal. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by strong winds and large waves. We will update this message by 09:00 on 26/11/2022.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Evenlode and the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland will continue tonight, 25/11/22. We are not expecting rainfall over the night tonight, but some showers will cross the area Saturday evening. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated on Saturday, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 2 am today, 25/11/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks Crew Green 5.4m to 5.5m Saturday morning, Montford 4.5m to 4.8m Saturday afternoon, Welshbridge 2.3m to 2.5m Saturday evening, Buildwas 3.4m to 3.6m Sunday morning, Bridgnorth 2.9m to 3.3m Sunday.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 27/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes

items.description: South Hayling and South Eastoke seafront
items.message: The lunchtime tide today at Portsmouth came in as forecast at 5.06 metres Chart Datum (2.33 mAOD). Impacts were not as severe as expected. Saturday’s very early morning tide at 00:18 on the 26/11/2022 is elevated but not expected to be as high. Saturday’s lunchtime tide at 12:30 on the 26/11/2022 is forecast at 5.12 metres Chart Datum (2.39 mAOD). These may cause minor impact flooding to coastal roads and car parks. A Flood Alert will remain in force to describe the impacts of these tides. We continue to monitor the forecast, and are liaising with the local authority and their response teams over the condition of the beach at South Hayling. The excavator has been on site re-forming the beach crest. At high tide, waves and water may be higher up the beach than normal. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by strong winds and large waves.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels are still high on the Bear Brook in Western Turnville. Flooding of areas next to the river is still possible but not expected. We will continue to monitor the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Sandhurst river gauge.  Tides will be at their highest at 22:15 this evening and at 10:30 tomorrow morning, Saturday 26/11/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore and Sandhurst Lane. Base Lane, Sandhurst may also flood. A417 Over to Maisemore maybe closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.7m to 4m at 22:45 this evening 25/11/22, 3.7m to 4m at 11:00 tomorrow morning 26/11/22. Gloucester 3.4m to 3.7m at 22:15 this evening 25/11/2022, 3.4m to 3.7m at 10:30 tomorrow morning 26/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week, especially around Islip. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We are not expecting rainfall over night tonight, but some showers will cross the area Saturday evening. We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

Saturday's early morning tide at 00:15 on 26/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by high energy waves. Winds are light Westerly Force 3. The weather increases tide table values by 0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 6.01 metres Chart Datum (2.96 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Saturday's midday tide will be very similar and minor impacts should be expected again. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 26/11/2022.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Dee.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. From approximately midday on 25/11/2022 Townfield Lane is likely to be cut off.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible during the next period of high tides up to and including Monday. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. Predicted Peaks:- at Mythe 3.5m to 3.7m this evening, 25/11/22 at around 11pm and 3.6-3.8m Saturday morning at approximately 11:15am; Upper Pound 3.5m to 3.7m 25/11/22 at approximately 11pm this evening 25/11/22 and 3.6-3.8m Saturday morning at approximately 11:15am.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast from Saturday afternoon and into the evening. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and closing flood gates.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 on 26/11/22, or as the situation changes.
